instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_FB: What is LCDBKLT_FB? LCDBKLT_FB is a feedback line between backlight output and the feedback pin on the LED driver. When this connection is broken, backlight output will be equal to PPBUS_G3H voltage of the system rather than boosting. Since this point is the highest voltage in the system, it is the fastest to corrode when liquid damaged, so it is a very common point to check when there is no backlight. .
definitions.BKL_SDA: What is BKL_SDA? BKL_SDA is an SMBUS data line between the LED driver and the system management controller(SMC).
definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
Water damages around bcklight driver changes couple cap and reg and found
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL>=18v and slowly drop 8.56v
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>=2.8v
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>=0v
 Remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and connect PWM directly to 3V ( <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR> ) and i see it works.
Is it the permanent fix or is there any demerits.Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
First of all, do PRAM reset.
Is <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message: This is not a fix that will keep full brightness forever, and that's not necessary on a 00165. Put <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> back and tells us exactly what voltage you get on backlight output.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
After Put <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> back 
bklight output at <CAPACITOR>C8317</CAPACITOR>=18v and slowly drop 8.56v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message: Did you already replace the LED driver and components near it? This sounds like an <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> issue if voltage is dropping like that. Tried known good DC in board and flat cable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message: Yes i replace the Led driver and now i see bklight output at <CAPACITOR>C8317</CAPACITOR>=8.56v and i tried good known DC in board and flat cable too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
If you got 18V, then 8.5V after replacing <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, I bet for bad solders.
Reflow the chip, it supports very good the heat.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message: Before replacing <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> i got 18V, then 8.5V . After replacing now i got 8.5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
If you didn't touch anything else, should get same voltage like before.
I suppose no good solders on the chip.
Post resistance to ground on all its connections, diode mode, red probe to ground.
Use surrounding components as test points.
Let the board to cool down first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
resistance to ground on all its connections, diode mode
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>=.315
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>=.411
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL>=OL
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL>=.582
<SIGNAL>BKL_ISEN1</SIGNAL>=.584
<SIGNAL>BKL_ISEN3</SIGNAL>=.584
<SIGNAL>BKL_ISEN5</SIGNAL>=0L
<SIGNAL>BKL_ISEN6</SIGNAL>=OL

<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>=.517
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>=.486
<SIGNAL>BKL_SDA</SIGNAL>=.430
 <SIGNAL>BKL_SCL</SIGNAL>=.430
<SIGNAL>BKL_FSET</SIGNAL>=.519
<SIGNAL>BKL_ISET</SIGNAL>=.516
<SIGNAL>BKL_FLTR</SIGNAL>=OL
<SIGNAL>BKL_VSYNC_R</SIGNAL>=OL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message: Bad soldering on the LED driver or blown feedback/switch line from the LED driver

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
As I told you, bad solders...
All ISENx lines should have (very) similar value.
OL means ball not soldered (under <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>), or blown Isense resistor; depends which point you checked the value.

BTW, you have bad solders  on other lines too, not only Isense...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message: I reflow LED driver and now it works. You guys awesome, Thanks a lot you all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 45778"]This is not a fix that will keep full brightness forever, and that's not necessary on a 00165. Put <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> back and tells us exactly what voltage you get on backlight output.[/QUOTE]

why won't that keep it full brightness forever?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
threads.message: It WILL keep it at full brightness forever which is not necessary unless it's an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>/5 for a bandaid fix. His problem was bad soldering on the driver. He corrected it now it's working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No back light
